title: Learn SQL with Step-by-Step Visual Execution
cardcontent: Ananya wants to show only the top 3 highest-scoring students. She remembers SQL has a LIMIT keyword to restrict the number of rows returned!
content2: We will use the student table:
card2content: LIMIT helps you control how many rows you want to display. Instead of showing the entire table

table1.title: Top 3 Highest Scorers
table1.code: SELECT name, marks FROM students ORDER BY marks DESC LIMIT 3;

table2.word: Displays the lowest-scoring students by limiting the output.
table2.title: Bottom 2 Lowest Scorers
table2.code: SELECT name, marks FROM students ORDER BY marks ASC LIMIT 2;

table3.word: Skips top results and retrieves the next set using LIMIT with OFFSET. The first two highest (Sneha: 92, Priya: 90) are skipped.
table3.title: Students Ranked 3 to 5
table3.code: SELECT name, marks FROM students ORDER BY marks DESC LIMIT 3 OFFSET 2;

table4.title: Top 1 Student in Each Department
table4.word: Finds the highest scorer in every department using a correlated subquery (Max per Group).
table4.code:
SELECT name, department, marks
FROM students s
WHERE marks = (
  SELECT MAX(marks)
  FROM students
  WHERE department = s.department
)
ORDER BY department ASC;

multicont.word1: Get all student records sorted by marks DESC
multicont.word2: Skip the top 2 students using OFFSET 2
multicont.word3: Limit the result set to the next 2 students (ranks 3 and 4) using LIMIT 2
